Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: An open class is scheduled at the school, and the step-parent should attend
Situation2: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the calendar app glaring back at me with two overlapping events. My stepson’s open class was at 2:00 PM, the same time as our team’s final meeting before the project launch. My partner had gently reminded me last night, “It would mean a lot to him if you were there. He’s been talking about it all week.” I could still see the hope in my stepson’s eyes when he asked if I’d come.

But at work, the pressure was mounting. My manager had emphasized how crucial this meeting was—everyone’s input needed, no exceptions. We’d been working on this project for months, and my absence would be noticed. I could already imagine the disappointed looks from my team, the subtle shift in trust if I didn’t show up.

I felt torn, my chest tight with anxiety. I wanted to be the supportive step-parent my family needed, but I also didn’t want to let my colleagues down. The clock ticked closer to two, and I sat frozen, wrestling with the impossible choice between two worlds that both expected me to show up.
